content:
The American Philosophical Society (APS) had connections with several intellectual and scientific organizations in the 18th and 19th centuries. These connections included:

1. Royal Society of London: The APS maintained a close relationship with the Royal Society of London. Several members of the APS were also members of the Royal Society, and the two organizations exchanged publications and research findings.

2. Académie des Sciences of Paris: The APS had a connection with the Académie des Sciences of Paris, which was one of the most prestigious scientific organizations in Europe. This allowed for the exchange of ideas and research findings between the two organizations.

3. American Academy of Arts and Sciences: The APS had a friendly relationship with the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, which was founded in 1780. The two organizations shared a common interest in promoting learning and research in the sciences and humanities.

4. Smithsonian Institution: The APS worked closely with the Smithsonian Institution, which was established in 1846. The Smithsonian and APS shared similar goals for promoting research and education in the sciences and humanities.

5. American Association for the Advancement of Science: The APS was a founding member of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which was established in 1848. The two organizations worked together on various projects and shared a common goal of promoting scientific research and education.
